column13: The James Hardie Supplier Code of Conduct sets out the principles, standards, and expectations that James Hardie holds for its employees and suppliers to support, embrace and adhere to. Suppliers are expected to adhere to this Code and the applicable laws and regulations in the jurisdictions in which they operate. James Hardie expects that suppliers embed the elements of this Code into the way they do business and the standards they have for their supply chain.

column6: Operations assessed for risks related to corruption
Communication and training about anti-corruption policies and procedures
column13: James Hardie is committed to ensuring a workplace free from bribery and corruption. This zero-tolerance is endorsed and supported by senior management and the Board. All employees must comply with the Company's Anti-Bribery and Corruption Policy. All complaints are initially reported directly to the Chief Legal Counsel and Chief Compliance Officer, Employment Counsel, Chief Human Resources Officer and the Director of Internal Audit.
column20: Anti-Bribery and Corruption Policy, bribery, corruption, complaint

column6: Confirmed incidents of corruption and actions taken
column7: James Hardie had two employees dismissed or disciplined for corruption cases in 2023.

column13: James Hardie's Antitrust Compliance Policy aims to preserve a competitive economy where free enterprise can flourish. The Company's insistence upon full compliance with the antitrust laws is based on its desire to stay within the bounds of the law and its conviction that preserving a free, competitive economy is essential.

Interactions with water as a shared resource
column13: James Hardie's Global Water Technology Development Committee aims to develop cost-effective water recycling and treatment technology to meet changing discharge limits while proactively reducing wastewater discharge. The committee uses cross-functional efforts to validate new technologies and deploy them as needed across James Hardie's operations, evaluate and respond to regulatory requirements, monitor business risk and consider joint development with external organisations.
column20: Global Water Technology Development Committee, water recycling, wastewater discharge

column6: Management of water discharge-related impacts
column13: In Reno, Nevada, James Hardie partners with an adjacent mine operator to provide process wastewater for beneficial reuse, replacing potable water use. In 2022, the effort avoided using more than 29 million gallons of drinking water, significantly reducing the plant's discharge water.
column20: Wastewater processing, mine operator, potable water use
